title: 113_s2065
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alternative Fuel Vehicle Development Act" and pertains to alternative fuel vehicles. The "Alternative Fuel Vehicle Development Act" introduces amendments to increase fuel economy for alternative fuel automobiles and set minimum driving ranges for dual-fueled passenger automobiles starting from model year 2016. The amendment sets a minimum driving range of 150 miles for alternative fueled automobiles starting from model year 2016. Starting from model year 2015, the Administrator will calculate fuel economy for gaseous fuel dual fueled automobiles as a weighted harmonic average of fuel economy on gaseous fuel and gasoline or diesel fuel. Manufacturers can choose to use utility factors for fuel economy calculations starting from model year 2017. The Administrator may measure fuel economy for electric dual fueled automobiles manufactured after 2015 by dividing 1.0 by the sum of certain factors. The Administrator may establish utility factors for electric automobiles based on their fuel utilization percentages and alternative fuel range. These factors can be adapted for alternative fueled automobiles that do not use specified fuels. Manufacturers may use alternative calculations if needed. The Administrator can establish utility factors for electric automobiles based on fuel utilization percentages and alternative fuel range. Manufacturers have the option to request alternative calculations for manufacturing incentives for electric dual fueled automobiles after model year 2015. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to section 32906(b) of title 49, United States Code. SEC. 3. HIGH OCCUPANCY VEHICLE FACILITIES. Amends Section 166 of title 23, United States Code to allow certain vehicles to use HOV facilities. SEC. 4. STUDY. Conducts a study. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The report will outline options to promote the development of public compressed natural gas fueling stations and analyze various financing tools, such as Federal grants, public-private partnerships, and membership-based cooperatives.
